title: 111_s1199
content: The "Air Medical Service Safety Improvement Act of 2009" aims to increase safety for helicopter and fixed-wing emergency medical service operators and patients. The "Air Medical Service Safety Improvement Act of 2009" requires helicopter and fixed-wing aircraft certificate holders providing emergency medical services to comply with part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations within 18 months of enactment, regardless of whether patients are on board. Exceptions apply for operations under instrument flight rules or training. The "Air Medical Service Safety Improvement Act of 2009" mandates compliance with part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations for helicopter and fixed-wing aircraft emergency medical service operators within 18 months of enactment. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration will create a standardized checklist of risk evaluation factors for operators to use in determining flight risks. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration will initiate a rulemaking within 60 days to require helicopter and fixed-wing emergency medical service operators to formalize performance-based flight dispatch procedures. The rulemaking must be completed within 18 months of initiation. The rulemaking for helicopter and fixed-wing emergency medical service operators must be completed within 18 months of initiation. Additionally, all such aircraft must have a terrain awareness and warning system on board within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Federal Aviation Administration will also require certificate holders for these aircraft to improve the data available on air medical operations. The Federal Aviation Administration requires helicopter and fixed-wing emergency medical service operators to report annually on the number of aircraft, flights, and purposes of each flight used for air ambulance services. The Federal Aviation Administration mandates annual reporting by helicopter and fixed-wing emergency medical service operators on aircraft usage for air ambulance services. The Administrator must report to Congress within 18 months of enactment on data related to voice and flight data recording devices for helicopters and fixed-wing aircraft used in emergency medical service operations. The Federal Aviation Administration will issue regulations within a year to require voice and flight data recording devices on aircraft used for emergency medical service operations.
